text: Nous avons adoré le poulet. Les portions sont généreuse et nous avons eus un super services. L'ambiance était très agréable et nous y retournerons avec joie.

This restaurant is so over hyped! Maybe my expectations were too high after everything I heard. Firstly it's very Indian influenced. I thought the chicken was like roasted/Portuguese. Not at all it was tandoori (12$ for quarter chicken). Nowhere did I read this before. The ribs ($15 for 4) are also "differently" spiced. Disappointed by the fact that they were not at all like traditional bbq ribs. The pouting was very good though ($6). For a Wednesday night we still had to wait 45 minutes. I don't blame them though they all work really hard! I guess it doesn't help that I really don't like Indian food.

Une rareté dans le quartier Tétreaultville: un resto pour foodies.  L'idée est de s'inspirer de la cuisine traditionnelle québécoise "poulet bbq" en passant le tout dans le filtre de cuisine hipster à la mode de Brooklyn.  Le décor est d'ambiance taverne de Montréal des années 1960. Un peu trop réaliste à mon goût car l'éclairage est assez cru et rend le teint blafard.  Le choix de bières est limité mais très original.  Nous avons pris la soupe au porc et les cigares aux choux pour entrées. Le quart de poulet et kes côtes levées comme plat principal. On était loin des plats traditionnels qui portent les même noms ce qui est un peu dommage.  Mais la qualité était au rendez-vous.  Je vais y retourner, c'est certain.

Great value for great food. The chicken was moist and the flavours were unique. Classic rotisserie with Asian flavours. The bread was homemade too which was a nice touch. Would go back even though the location is out of the way.
Meilleur poulet BBQ de l'Est de Montréal! Menu du jour créatif, bon choix de vins à prix compétitifs. Il n'y a pas assez de restaurants comme cela dans l'Est!
Service affreux. Le personnel n'est pas aimable et ne fait aucun effort pour sa clientèle. Ils semblent complètement dépassés et énervés des qu'il y a beaucoup de monde.

Pretty legit place for rotisserie chicken with a touch of Indian spices!!! Definitely better than most rotisserie places and a welcoming ambiance and decor. It opened in September and now there's a lot of traction. The place was packed as soon as it opened Saturday at 5pm! Definitely good value and good food ;)

Wow. So good. We were staying in Montreal on a trip from NYC. We heard about this place, which is admittedly a little far from the center city. It could not be more worth the trek. We had a lovely metro ride and walk to the restaurant, which is casual and fun. They have a great wine, beer and cocktail selection. Their menu is brief but phenomenal, which is supplemented by a number of delicious and changing specials. We got a liverwurst ravioli with fried egg to start, it was great! Then we split a half tandoor chicken, chef salad and converted our side of fries into poutine. It was plenty of food, and it was so delicious. The salad was one of the best I've ever had - simple and so well seasoned and dressed. The chicken was succulent, flavorful and tender. It was really awesome. The poutine was great - tons of gravy.   We would come here once a week if we lived here, and it is DEFINITELY worth the journey. Staff is super friendly, knowledgeable and helpful.   Cash only.

Okay this is a way away from main Montreal... but oh so worth it!  We got the 1/2 chicken and the fried ribs.  Both are served with crunchy and perfect fries and bread and cole slaw.  It was sooooo good.  The chicken is just extraordinary.  It's chicken with a tandoori flair.  The ribs were crunchy and succulent with this amazing mustard sauce. We couldn't finish it all, because it's a lot of food.  Glad to have some leftover.  The decor here is cute and punky.  Feels like a hipster diner. The owners are incredibly friendly.  Oh almost forgot about the cocktail...I got the basil gimlet...sooo good.  Honestly one of the best chicken places I've ever been too!

Yay for adventures with Bartek! We drove out to Tetrauville because last time he tried this restaurant they had been out of the whole, half and quarter chicken. Following a glowing review by Eve Dumas in La Presse this tiny odd delicious spot experienced a wave of excited customers. They are still feeling the effects but the lines are gone and the staff are hitting their stride and it's a perfect time to head out on a Chicken Adventure.   We were able to sit right away and enjoy the collection of vintage beer bottles and jars of pickled peppers on the walls. We started with a delicious Paloma cocktail and ordered a quarter chicken which came perfectly moist and spicy with Pakistani seasoning and fries and coleslaw - all homemade and perfect; a giant and crazy interesting Poutine au Coq with beautiful tender chicken, gravy with butter chicken spices, and chimichurri on top. We also shared an excellent Ceasar salad with whole pieces of freshly cooked bacon, and an order of the special Hakka chicken wings which are officially my favourite chicken wings. Everything was cooked to order, made with great quality ingredients and exciting flavours. The co-owners come from vast restaurant experience including Liverpool House and APDC so you can taste all this high level food nerd pedigree but the room and the vibe is completely unpretentious, friendly, funny, part of the neighbourhood.  I wish them all the love and success and can't wait to go back.

This is a place worth driving half an hour for, and I've done it a couple times this year already.  The rotisserie chicken is prepared with tandoori flavours and roasted tender and juicy. Fries and double fried ( I think) and are some of the best I've had. And the coleslaw, my favourite coleslaw.  They could make the Caesar salad a bit less salty and they could maybe use one more helping hand ( or more efficient ). The girl at the front does everything from cashier to bartender to server to putting fries into the fryer...while two other guys in the kitchen do much less...  With all of the above, still a five star for me
Un des meilleurs poulet rôti que j'ai goûté. Sauce juste assez épicé avec des épices qui donnent une saveur particulièrement excellente. Place très charmante et conviviale

C'est le Resto de poulet rôti revisité. Poulet style tandouri, délicieuse ribs, c'est original et bien fait: tout était bon! En plus, le Resto a un décor relax et accueillant. Ne tenez pas compte des commentaires sur le mauvais service, c'est tout faux! En tout cas, quand nous y sommes allés , c'était poli et efficace.

Ma copine avait lu sur La Presse, un bon article concernant cet ancien resto de serveuses sexy converti en septembre 2015 à Tétreauville par de jeunes entrepreneurs qui avaient faits leurs armes dans l'industrie de la restauration montréalaise, en rôtisserie nouveau genre. On été de passage en plus à Tétreauville, donc nous y sommes allés pour souper. Oui, enfin, un restaurant hipster dans l'Est de Montréal, j'encourage ce développement dans ce coin de la ville, ça en prendrait plus. Y'avait beaucoup de monde, c'était un samedi soir, jeunes couples, petites familles, assez populaire quoi. Déco rétro avec de la récupération, très simple + céramique blanche au mur. Prix abordables. Bon service avec sourire de la serveuse qui était aussi la propriétaire avec son conjoint. Maintenant, au niveau de la bouffe, menu simple, comfort food, ma copine a pris la poutine au Coq (12$) et moi, leur fameux poulet tandoori + frites (12$) + entrée salade césar (7$) pour partager avec ma copine. La salade était correcte, sans plus, mon ¼ de poulet tandoori était bon et tendre, mais c'était pas en m'en roulé par terre. Pas impressionné. Conclusion, content pour les gens qui veulent un resto confort food / foodie bien dans le coin qui veulent pas venir dans le Mile-End/Plateau/Griffintown, mais je pense pas que je reviendrais en voiture ou en métro depuis le Plateau pour manger un poulet tandoori nouveau genre ou encore une poutine. C'était bien, un soir, mais c'est tout.  3,5/5 visité en septembre 2016.
